columns.text: In this problem. we will compare two different types of depreciation calculations and determine which is better.

Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) of computing for the depreciation by solving for the depreciation of a company's tangible assets. This means that a larger tax deduction is given in the earlier life of the asset while a smaller deduction is given at the latter end of the asset's life.

Straight line depreciation means that the asset loses the same value every year until the end of its lifespan. This is solved by dividing the difference between the cost and its expected salvage value by the estimated lifespan.

It is better to choose the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery system of solving for the depreciation since it provides a larger tax deduction and the succeeding deductions are dependent on the depreciation of the asset. This means that the cost of acquiring the asset is more easily recovered since it does not follow the same set amount of deduction every year.
This question requires us to choose what preference of firm to be used between MACRS depreciation or straight-line depreciation.

A company might choose **MACRS depreciation** for taxation purposes since it allows for more significant amortization rebates sooner. Such relatively large repayments lower the tax rate and have no other monetary implications. The alternative among both MACRS and straight-line depreciation is solely a matter of intangible value; the cumulative devaluation would be the same, only the duration would vary. 


On the other hand, **straight-line depreciation** seems to be a more conservative technique even if it is not ramped up, with substantial cash flows occurring earlier in the dateline. As a result, the net value of either the tax rebate or impairment loss is not as intense.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
